==Meta-ethics==
 
==Meta-ethics==
 
{{main|Meta-ethics}}
 
{{main|Meta-ethics}}
−
'''Meta-ethics''' is the investigation into the nature of ethical concepts and [[proposition|propositions]]. It involves such questions as: are ethical claims truth-apt (i.e. capable of being true or false), or are they, for example, expressions of emotion, the nature of actions, and intentions? If they are truth-apt, are they ever true? If they are ever true, what is the nature of the facts that they express? And are they ever true absolutely (see [[moral absolutism]]), or always only relative to some individual, society, or culture (see [[moral relativism]] and [[cultural relativism]])?
+
'''Meta-ethics''' is the investigation into the nature of ethical concepts and [[proposition|propositions]]. It involves such questions as: are ethical claims truth-apt (i.e. capable of being true or false), or are they expressions of emotion, "implicit" imperatives, or something else? If they are truth-apt, are they ever true? If they are ever true, what is the nature of the facts that they express? And are they ever true absolutely (see [[moral absolutism]]), or always only relative to some individual, society, or culture (see [[moral relativism]] and [[cultural relativism]])?
     
===Ethical propositions and truth-aptitude===
